R for Medical Research 3

Reshape and Join

Author

Matt Broerman

Published

October 10, 2022

Overview

Today we will convert data from a long format to a wide format, and join together separate datasets. This completes the basic data manipulation series.

Load Data

Demographics

We will use this toy dataset.

set.seed(123)

id <- paste0("id", seq(1:6))
dob <- 
  sample(seq(as.Date('1999/01/01'),
             as.Date('2000/01/01'),
             by="day"), 6)
dod <- 
  sample(seq(as.Date('2016/01/01'),
             as.Date('2017/01/01'),
             by="day"), 6)
weight <- 
  rnorm(n = 6, mean = 170, sd = 5)

demo <- 
  tibble(id, dob, dod, weight) |> 
  # id6 lost to follow-up
  head(5)
# A tibble: 5 × 4
  id    dob        dod        weight
  <chr> <date>     <date>      <dbl>
1 id1   1999-06-28 2016-08-16   167.
2 id2   1999-01-14 2016-08-31   168.
3 id3   1999-07-14 2016-01-14   176.
4 id4   1999-11-02 2016-06-01   172.
5 id5   1999-04-28 2016-03-30   172.

Trial data

And this toy dataset.

id2 <- rep(id, times = 2)
trt <- rep(c("trt", "crl"), 
           times = 6)
vst <- rep(c("vst1", "vst2"), 
           each = 6)
res <- c(rnorm(3, 10, 1), 
         rnorm(3, 10, 1), 
         rnorm(3, 12, 1), 
         rnorm(3, 17, 1))

trial <- tibble(id2, vst, trt) |> 
  arrange(vst, trt) |> 
  mutate(res = res) |> 
  arrange(vst, id2)

trial[12, 4] <- NA
# A tibble: 12 × 4
   id2   vst   trt     res
   <chr> <chr> <chr> <dbl>
 1 id1   vst1  trt    8.03
 2 id2   vst1  crl    9.44
 3 id3   vst1  trt   10.7 
 4 id4   vst1  crl   11.8 
 5 id5   vst1  trt    9.53
 6 id6   vst1  crl   10.5 
 7 id1   vst2  trt   16.3 
 8 id2   vst2  crl   10.9 
 9 id3   vst2  trt   16.4 
10 id4   vst2  crl   11.8 
11 id5   vst2  trt   15.3 
12 id6   vst2  crl   NA

Reshape

Long to Wide (Pivot)

trial |> 
  pivot_wider(id_cols = id2, names_from = vst, values_from = res)
# A tibble: 6 × 3
  id2    vst1  vst2
  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>
1 id1    8.03  16.3
2 id2    9.44  10.9
3 id3   10.7   16.4
4 id4   11.8   11.8
5 id5    9.53  15.3
6 id6   10.5   NA

Notice that we loose the treatment variable.

Calculate

trial_wide <- trial |> 
  pivot_wider(id_cols = id2, names_from = vst, values_from = res) |> 
  mutate(diff_vst = vst2 - vst1)

trial_wide
# A tibble: 6 × 4
  id2    vst1  vst2 diff_vst
  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>
1 id1    8.03  16.3  8.24   
2 id2    9.44  10.9  1.49   
3 id3   10.7   16.4  5.67   
4 id4   11.8   11.8 -0.00489
5 id5    9.53  15.3  5.79   
6 id6   10.5   NA   NA

Now we can add on the difference, and save the result to a new variable.

Join

Left Join

demo |> 
  left_join(trial_wide, by = c("id" = "id2"))
# A tibble: 5 × 7
  id    dob        dod        weight  vst1  vst2 diff_vst
  <chr> <date>     <date>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>
1 id1   1999-06-28 2016-08-16   167.  8.03  16.3  8.24   
2 id2   1999-01-14 2016-08-31   168.  9.44  10.9  1.49   
3 id3   1999-07-14 2016-01-14   176. 10.7   16.4  5.67   
4 id4   1999-11-02 2016-06-01   172. 11.8   11.8 -0.00489
5 id5   1999-04-28 2016-03-30   172.  9.53  15.3  5.79

Usually you have one main dataset, and you want to add to it. You don’t care about everything in the other dataset. This is a “left join,” and the most common.

Full Join

demo |> 
  full_join(trial_wide, by = c("id" = "id2"))
# A tibble: 6 × 7
  id    dob        dod        weight  vst1  vst2 diff_vst
  <chr> <date>     <date>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>
1 id1   1999-06-28 2016-08-16   167.  8.03  16.3  8.24   
2 id2   1999-01-14 2016-08-31   168.  9.44  10.9  1.49   
3 id3   1999-07-14 2016-01-14   176. 10.7   16.4  5.67   
4 id4   1999-11-02 2016-06-01   172. 11.8   11.8 -0.00489
5 id5   1999-04-28 2016-03-30   172.  9.53  15.3  5.79   
6 id6   NA         NA            NA  10.5   NA   NA

Full joins treat both datasets as equal, and includes all data from both sets. Notice id6 shows up again.

Anti Join (reverse)

trial_wide |> 
  anti_join(demo, by = c("id2" = "id"))
# A tibble: 1 × 4
  id2    vst1  vst2 diff_vst
  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>
1 id6    10.5    NA       NA

Here, we are getting all the rows in trial_wide that are not in demo.

Semi Join (reverse)

trial_wide |> 
  semi_join(demo, by = c("id2" = "id"))
# A tibble: 5 × 4
  id2    vst1  vst2 diff_vst
  <chr> <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>
1 id1    8.03  16.3  8.24   
2 id2    9.44  10.9  1.49   
3 id3   10.7   16.4  5.67   
4 id4   11.8   11.8 -0.00489
5 id5    9.53  15.3  5.79

Here, we are getting only the rows in trial_wide that are also in demo (but not the columns from it)
